Title: Found Again
Credits: Created by Ryo Safadi. Template by Adam Smith.

Surface.Body:
A clear sky, a soft breeze. A perfect day, some may say.
And yet, the pond that lies before you, the one you've known all your life, has turned dark and gray. You've been avoiding it, fearing what lies below.
Now, it is time to face the truth.

Underwater.Body:
You jump in.
Now fully submerged, you open your eyes and look around. You are shrouded in darkness, with no hint as to what is corrupting your beloved pond.
You must search for an answer.

Plants.Body:
You come across what appears to be a forest of vines.
Upon closer inspection, you realize that these are the stems of the water lilies that once bloomed here.
Sinking between the stems is the last lily flower; its pink color, fading.

Catfish.Body:
You get swarmed by a school of Catfish.
However, they don't seem to notice you. They continue slowly moving along, devoid of any destination.

Mussels.Body: The ocean floor is covered in mussels and lined with water-thyme. They are completely still, as if frozen in time.

Watch.Body:
You see something resting on the sediment.
It's a gold watch, but it doesn't seem to be working.
Watch.MechanismMsg:
After gently shaking the watch, the second hand starts to tick!
But, it probably won't last long.

Tombstone.Body:
There is some sort of stone tablet half-buried in ground. You run your fingers along it, feeling the texture of the engravings.
It is too dark to read, but maybe if you had a light...

End.Body:
You place the flower next to the stone.
It's color returns instantly, as if that's where it has always belonged.
The flower begins to glow. A sudden flash of light blinds you.
You open your eyes once again, but this time, the water is clear. You look around at all the wildlife, now restored. Your pond has returned to it's former glory.
You look at the stone, it's engraving now visible. It has but one word, a name.
The burial place of someone once loved. Their soul has become the source of life for this habitat.
Now, their memory lives on through you and your pond.
